o: A source distribution that must be compiled
A built distribution format that speeds up installation
A script used to automate virtual environment creation
A tool for managing multiple Python versions
data.e: Wheels are a 'built' distribution format. Unlike source distributions (sdist), they don't require a build/compile step on the user's machine, making installation much faster.

data.q: Which tool is the standard utility used to upload distribution packages to PyPI?
data.e: `twine` is the recommended tool for uploading packages to PyPI because it securely handles file uploads and doesn't execute `setup.py` during the process.

data.q: What does a 'pure Python' wheel mean?
o: It only works on Linux systems
It contains only Python code and no C extensions
It is compatible only with the latest Python version
data.e: A pure Python wheel contains only Python code. Because it doesn't have compiled C extensions, the same wheel file can work on any operating system.

data.q: Which of the following is a 'platform wheel' filename suffix for a 64-bit Windows system?
data.e: Platform wheels contain compiled code and are specific to an OS and architecture. `win_amd64` indicates a 64-bit Windows build.

data.q: What is the standard command to build both a source distribution and a wheel using the `build` module?
data.e: While the `setup.py` method is older, `python -m build` (from the `build` package) is the modern, PEP 517-consistent way to generate distributions.

o: To run unit tests for your project
A separate instance of PyPI for testing the publishing process
A repository for beta-version software only
A tool for checking package security vulnerabilities
data.e: TestPyPI allows developers to practice the upload process and verify metadata without affecting the real Python Package Index.

data.q: What does the `manylinux` tag in a wheel filename refer to?
o: A wheel that requires a specific Linux distribution like Ubuntu
A wheel compatible across most common Linux distributions
A wheel that only works on server-side hardware
A package that supports multiple Python interpreters
data.e: The `manylinux` standard (like `manylinux2014`) ensures that binary wheels are compiled against a sufficiently old `glibc` to be compatible with almost all modern Linux distros.

data.q: Which file provides the metadata used by PyPI to display the project description on its website?
data.e: PyPI uses the `long_description` field (usually read from the README file) to render the project's home page on the index.

data.q: Which command allows you to check if your distribution's metadata will render correctly on PyPI?
data.e: `twine check` validates that your package description is in a valid format (like reStructuredText or Markdown) that PyPI can render.

data.q: What happens if you try to upload a wheel with the same version number as one already existing on PyPI?
o: The upload fails with an error
data.e: PyPI does not allow overwriting or reusing version numbers. Once a version is published, you must increment the version number for a new upload.

data.q: Why are wheels preferred over source distributions (sdist) for packages with C extensions?
o: They take up less disk space
They don't require the user to have a C compiler installed
data.e: Because wheels are pre-compiled, the user doesn't need a compiler or development headers (like `python-dev`) to install the package.

data.q: In the wheel filename `cryptography-3.4.8-cp36-abi3-manylinux_2_24_x86_64.whl`, what does `cp36` represent?
data.e: The `cp36` tag indicates the Python implementation (CPython) and version (3.6) that the wheel was built for.
